items.synopsis: US Coast Guard authorities confirm the destruction of the missing Titan submersible and the deaths of those on board,Â announcing a "debris field" was found near the Titanic wreck. Follow live.

title.children: Questions raised over doomed sub's design as investigation turns to cause of disaster

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Movie director and submersible maker James Cameron says he wishes he had sounded the alarm earlier about the submersible Titan that imploded on an expedition to the Titanic wreckage, saying he had found the hull design risky. All five aboard the vessel were killed. Cameron became a deep-sea explorer in the 1990s while researching and making his Oscar-winning blockbuster Titanic, and is part owner of Triton Submarines, which makes submersibles for research and tourism. He is part of the small and close-knit submersible community, or Manned Underwater Vehicle (MUV) industry. When he heard, as many in the industry had shared, that OceanGate Inc was making a deep-sea submersible with a composite carbon fiber and titanium hull, Cameron said he was skeptical. "I thought it was a horrible idea," Cameron told Reuters in a Zoom interview. "I wish I'd spoken up, but I assumed somebody was smarter than me, you know, because I never experimented with that technology, but it just sounded bad on its face." The cause of the Titan's implosion has not been determined, but Cameron presumes the critics were correct in warning that a carbon fiber and titanium hull would enable delamination and microscopic water ingress, leading to progressive failure over time. Other experts in the industry and a whistle-blowing employee raised alarms in 2018, criticising OceanGate for opting against seeking certification and operating as an experimental vessel. OceanGate has not addressed queries about its decision to forgo certification from industry third parties. The US Coast Guard said the submersible appears to have imploded, but a conclusive investigation will take time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: James Cameron says he wishes he'd sounded alarm over lost submersible

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Azmeh Dawood, the older sister of Pakistani businessman Shahzada Dawood, told NBC News her nephew, Suleman, was reluctant to go on the Titan expedition. In an interview with the outlet, Azmeh said the 19-year-old told a relative that he "wasn't very up for it" and felt "terrified" about the trip. But Suleman boarded the vessel because the trip fell over the Father's Day weekend. "I am thinking of Suleman, who is 19, in there, just perhaps gasping for breath ... It's been crippling, to be honest," Azmeh told NBC News. "I feel disbelief. It's an unreal situation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 19-year-old Titan passenger was 'terrified' before trip, his aunt says

props.alt: Suleman and Shahzada smile for a selfie at sunset.

children.content: Suleman and Shahzada.
(Reuters:Â Courtesy of Engro Corporation Limited)
Azmeh Dawood
, the older sister of Pakistani businessman
Shahzada Dawood
, told NBC News her nephew,
Suleman
, was
Â
reluctant to go on the Titan expedition.
In an interview with the outlet, Azmeh said the 19-year-old told a relative that he "wasn't very up for it" and felt "terrified" about the trip.
But Suleman boarded the vessel because the trip fell over the Father's Day weekend.
"I am thinking of Suleman, who is 19, in there, just perhaps gasping for breath ... It's been crippling, to be honest," Azmeh told NBC News.
"I feel disbelief. It's an unreal situation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liability waivers signed by passengers on the submersible lost at sea during a dive to the Titanic wreck may not shield OceanGate from potential lawsuits by the victims' families, legal experts said. The passengers, who paid as much as $US250,000 ($360,000) each for the journey to 3,810 meters below the surface, are believed to have signed liability waivers. A CBS reporter who made the trip with OceanGate Expeditions in July 2022 reported that the waiver he signed mentioned the possibility of death three times on the first page alone. Reuters could not independently confirm the terms of OceanGate's waivers. OceanGate did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Waivers are not always ironclad, and it is not uncommon for judges to reject them if there is evidence of gross negligence or hazards that were not fully disclosed. "If there were aspects of the design or construction of this vessel that were kept from the passengers or it was knowingly operated despite information that it was not suitable for this dive, that would absolutely go against the validity of the waiver," said personal injury attorney and maritime law expert Matthew Shaffer. OceanGate could argue it was not grossly negligent and that the waivers apply because they fully described the dangers inherent in plumbing the deepest reaches of the ocean in a submersible the size of a minivan. The degree of any potential negligence and how that might impact the applicability of the waivers will depend on the causes of the disaster, which are still under investigation. "There are so many different examples of what families might still have claims for despite the waivers, but until we know the cause we can't determine whether the waivers apply," said personal injury lawyer Joseph Low. The families could not be reached on Thursday. It is possible none of them will sue. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victims' families could still sue despite liability waivers, legal experts say

children.content: Liability waivers signed by passengers on the submersible lost at sea during a dive to the Titanic wreck may not shield OceanGate from potential lawsuits by the victims' families, legal experts said.
The passengers, who paid as much as $US250,000 ($360,000) each for the journey to 3,810 meters below the surface, are believed to have signed liability waivers.
A CBS reporter who made the trip with OceanGate Expeditions in July 2022 reported that the waiver he signed
mentioned the possibility of death three times on the first page alone.
(Supplied: OceanGate Expeditions)
Reuters could not independently confirm the terms of OceanGate's waivers. OceanGate did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Waivers are not always ironclad, and it is
not uncommon for judges to reject them if there is evidence of gross negligence
or hazards that were not fully disclosed.

"If there were aspects of the design or construction of this vessel that were kept from the passengers or it was knowingly operated despite information that it was not suitable for this dive, that would absolutely go against the validity of the waiver," said personal injury attorney and maritime law expert
Matthew Shaffer.
OceanGate could argue it was not grossly negligent and that the waivers apply because they
fully described the dangers
inherent in plumbing the deepest reaches of the ocean in a submersible the size of a minivan.
The degree of any potential negligence and how that might impact the applicability of the waivers
will depend on the causes of the disaster, which are still under investigation.

"There are so many different examples of what families might still have claims for despite the waivers, but until we know the cause we can't determine whether the waivers apply," said personal injury lawyer
Joseph Low.
The families could not be reached on Thursday. It is possible none of them will sue.
Reporting by Reuters

items.synopsis: US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell has signalled that more interest rate rises may be needed this year to get US inflation down, increasing fears they could hit a recession. Britain is also treading close to one. Follow the day's events and insights as they happenÂ withÂ our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.Â

title.children: Global recession fears rise as share market opens lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fitch Ratings has revised its house price forecasts, saying Australian home prices are recovering and are expected to grow 2 to 5 per cent, instead of a 10 per cent fall it had originally forecast for 2023. "Interest rates are continuing to increase, and housing affordability will remain a constraint on prices," the agency said in a statement.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian house prices to rise

children.content: Fitch Ratings has revised its house price forecasts, saying Australian home prices are recovering and are expected to grow 2 to 5 per cent, instead of a 10 per cent fall it had originally forecast for 2023.
"Interest rates are continuing to increase, and housing affordability will remain a constraint on prices," the agency said in a statement.

props.alt: A row of houses seen from above

children.content: House prices are increasing nationally.
(Â (Andrew Merry / Moment / Getty Images))

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 index opened weaker and was trading 0.32 per cent lower at 7172.8 at 10.20am AEST. On Wall Street, the S & P 500 gained 0.4 per cent and the Nasdaq index rose nearly 1 per cent. But the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.1 per cent lower. The Aussie dollar is trading near US67.62 cents. US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell has signaled that more interest rate rises may be needed this year to get US inflation down. US Fed officials held rates steady last week after 10 straight increases, giving themselves more time to evaluate the impact of aggressive rate hikes. Meanwhile the Bank of England has increased interest rates by an unexpected half-a-percentage point to a 15-year high and has also signaled more rate rises are to come.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Share market opens lower, global recession fears increase

children.content: The ASX 200 index opened weaker and was trading 0.32 per cent lower at 7172.8 at 10.20am AEST.
On Wall Street, the S
P 500 gained 0.4 per cent and the Nasdaq index rose nearly 1 per cent.
But the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.1 per cent lower.
The Aussie dollar is trading near US67.62 cents.
US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell has signaled that more interest rate rises may be needed this year to get US inflation down.
US Fed officials held rates steady last week after 10 straight increases, giving themselves more time to evaluate the impact of aggressive rate hikes.
Meanwhile the Bank of England has increased interest rates by an unexpected half-a-percentage point to a 15-year high and has also signaled more rate rises are to come.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fears are mounting that the British economy is heading for recession the Bank of England increased interest rates by an unexpected half-a-percentage point to a 15-year high. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and his ministers are feeling the pressure after back to back rate rises - this was the 13th in a row, and will make it harder for homeowners in Britain already hit by sharp hikes in the cost of food and fuel. The Bank of England said its nine-member Monetary Policy Committee cautioned that wages growth would likely slow from here. It said inflation should ease later in the year, and higher interest rates were yet to really bite the many Britons on fixed-rate mortgages. "There has been significant upside news in recent data that indicates more persistence in the inflation process, against the background of a tight labour market and continued resilience in demand," the MPC said in a statement after the meeting. It added that "if there were to be evidence of more persistent pressures, then further tightening in monetary policy would be required."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Britain heading towards a recession?

props.alt: Rishi Sunak in a blue suit

children.content: UK PM Rishi Sunak is facing pressure after 13 rate rises
(Reuters: John Sibley)
Fears are mounting that the British economy is heading for recession the Bank of England increased interest rates by an unexpected half-a-percentage point to a 15-year high.

Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and his ministers are feeling the pressure after back to back rate rises - this was the 13th in a row, and will make it harder for homeowners in Britain already hit by sharp hikes in the cost of food and fuel.
The Bank of England said its nine-member Monetary Policy Committee cautioned that wages growth would likely slow from here.
It said inflation should ease later in the year, and higher interest rates were yet to really bite the many Britons on fixed-rate mortgages.

"There has been significant upside news in recent data that indicates more persistence in the inflation process, against the background of a tight labour market and continued resilience in demand," the MPC said in a statement after the meeting.
It added that "if there were to be evidence of more persistent pressures, then further tightening in monetary policy would be required."
